paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can induce an interferon-rich inflammatory state that increases tumour sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical murine tumour models testing intratumoral mRNA vaccination in combination with anti-PD-L1 as an efficacy setting for tumour control and immune infiltration readouts.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched preclinical control groups used to distinguish combination effects from vaccine-only, ICI-only, or vehicle outcomes, and to support interpretation of sensitization versus standalone activity.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort under ICI
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Translational retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status to assess associations with survival outcomes.

major_limitations: Human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
